Def.Name: Colorado Spruce
Def.Description: Native tree growing 164' tall, the crown long-conic; branches whorled, ascending to slightly to strongly drooping.
Def.Leaves: Evergreen needles, borne singly and at right angles from all sides of the twig. 3/4" - 1 1/2" long, 4-angled, stiff and sharply spine-tipped, silvery to blue-green.
Def.Twigs: Not pendent, stout, yellow-brown, usually without hair; many small twigs produced on the main trunk and between the main whorls of branches.
Def.SeedConeOrFruit: Seed Cone: 2" - 4" long, green or violet, ripening pale buff (straw in color). Papery scales with irregularly toothed margins.
Def.Bark: Relatively thick, gray-brown, breaking into furrow and rounded ridges, only slightly scaly.
Def.Range: Central and southern Rocky Mountains of the USA ie) Idaho, Wyoming, Utah, Colorado, New Mexico and Arizona.
Def.Remarks: Because of its cold hardiness symmetrical pyramidal form, and waxy, blue-hued foliage, it is widely planted as an ornamental and used as Christamas trees. Otherwise brittle and full of knots.
